elements.content: Three 3D coordination polymers of {(H2bpy)[Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4]·8H2O} n (1), [Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)(H2O)2] n (2), and {[Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)3]·(bpy)·8H2O} n (3) (H3IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridyl) were hydrothermally synthesized by controlling the final pH values of the solutions of ca. 6, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In compound 1, unprecedented “double-square” units of [Cd4(μ3-HIDC)2(μ4-IDC)(μ5-IDC)]2 4- are linked by [Cd(bpy)2]2+ to generate a 1D chain of {[Cd8(μ3-HIDC)4(μ4-IDC)2(μ5-IDC)2]Cd(bpy)2} n 2 n -, and the 1D chains are further bridged by μ2-bpy to form a 2D brick-wall-like network of {[Cd8(μ3-HIDC)4(μ4-IDC)2(μ5-IDC)2(μ2-bpy)2]Cd(bpy)2} n 2 n - (≡ [Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4] n 2 n -). Each “brick” contains one protonated bpy ion of H2bpy2+ to get a neutral compound of {(H2bpy)[Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4]·8H2O} n . The adjacent 2D brick walls are perpendicularly packed and interlinked by μ4-IDC3- and μ5-IDC3- bridges to generate a 3D open framework of 1. The species of μ3-HIDC2-, μ4-IDC3-, μ5-IDC3-, H2bpy2+, μ2-bpy, and monodentate bpy coexist in compound 1. Compound 2 consists of 2D wavelike sheets of [Zn3(μ3-IDC)2(H2O)2], which are further linked through μ2-bpy to generate a 3D structure. In 3, the 2D honeycomb-like sheets of [Zn3(IDC)2] n are bridged by μ2-bpy to result in a 3D open framework with hexagonal and tetragonal channels. Compounds 1 and 2 are stable up to 320 and 400 °C, respectively, and display strong blue fluorescent emission at room temperature.

elements.content: In the past decade, coordination polymers have gained considerable attention due to their attractive structures and promising applications for catalysis, gas storage, magnetic materials, and optoelectronics. Recently, increasing investigations have been focused on the constructions of coordination polymers using heterocyclic carboxylic acids such as pyridine-, pyrazole-, and imidazole-carboxylic acids 4 as building blocks. These building blocks contain multi-oxygen and nitrogen atoms and can coordinate with metal ions in different ways, resulting in the formations of various metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with specific topologies and useful properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, coordination polymers have gained considerable attention due to their attractive structures and promising applications for catalysis, gas storage, magnetic materials, and optoelectronics. Recently, increasing investigations have been focused on the constructions of coordination polymers using heterocyclic carboxylic acids such as pyridine-, pyrazole-, and imidazole-carboxylic acids 4 as building blocks. These building blocks contain multi-oxygen and nitrogen atoms and can coordinate with metal ions in different ways, resulting in the formations of various metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with specific topologies and useful properties.

elements.content: We are interested in the coordination chemistry of imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3IDC), since it can be partially or fully deprotonated to generate H2IDC-, HIDC2-, and IDC3- anions (Scheme ) at different pH values. Therefore, it can coordinate with metal ions in multi-coordinated ways (Scheme ) to form a series of MOFs with different structures and interesting topologies and properties. Herein we report on the hydrothermal synthesis and structures of three 3D coordination polymers of {(H2bpy)[Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4]·8H2O} n (1), [Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)(H2O)2] n (2), and {[Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)3]·(bpy)·8H2O} n (3) (H3IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridyl), which are constructed by cadmium and zinc ions with imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate and 4,4‘-bipyridyl (bpy) building blocks.

Therefore, it can coordinate with metal ions in multi-coordinated ways (Scheme ) to form a series of MOFs with different structures and interesting topologies and properties. Herein we report on the hydrothermal synthesis and structures of three 3D coordination polymers of {(H2bpy)[Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4]⋅8H2O} n  (1), [Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)(H2O)2] n  (2), and {[Zn3(IDC)2(bpy)3]⋅(bpy)⋅8H2O} n  (3) (H3IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridyl), which are constructed by cadmium and zinc ions with imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate and 4,4‘-bipyridyl (bpy) building blocks.

General Remarks. Imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3IDC) was prepared from benzoimidazole in 65−75% yield. All of other chemicals are commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000−400 cm-1 region using KBr pellets and a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. Excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu RF-5301PC fluorescence spectrophotometer, using band pathways of 5 nm excitation and 5 nm emission at room temperature for the solid samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) data were collected on a Netzsch TG-209 instrument under air atmosphere in the temperature range 20−800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C /min. The variation temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2200 VPC diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Remarks. Imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3IDC) was prepared from benzoimidazole in 65-75% yield. All of other chemicals are commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 region using KBr pellets and a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. Excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu RF-5301PC fluorescence spectrophotometer, using band pathways of 5 nm excitation and 5 nm emission at room temperature for the solid samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) data were collected on a Netzsch TG-209 instrument under air atmosphere in the temperature range 20-800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C /min. The variation temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2200 VPC diffractometer.

elements.content: {(H 2 bpy)[Cd 9 (HIDC) 4 (IDC) 4 (bpy) 4 ] · 8H 2 O} n (1). A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.154 g, 0.50 mmol), H3IDC (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), bpy (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), pyridine (py, 0.50 mL), and water (10 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 180 °C for 3 days, followed by cooling to 100 °C at a rate of 10 °C /h, and held at this temperature for 10 h, then cooled to room temperature. The pH values of the solution before and after reactions are ca. 8 and 6, respectively. Colorless block crystals were collected by hand, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield:  43.8% based on Cd(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. found: C, 34.47, H, 1.96, N, 11.82%. Calcd for C90H62N26O36Cd9: C, 34.92, H, 2.02, N, 11.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3426 (m), 1602 (vs), 1475 (vs), 1378 (s), 1243 (s), 1107 (m), 805 (m), 664 (w), 630 (w).

elements.content: Compound 1 could also be obtained in various yields under the following hydrothermal conditions:  (1) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.50 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (0.50 mmol) + py (0.50 mL) + water (10 mL), 150 °C, 3 days; (2) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.25 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (0.50 mmol) + py (0.50 mL) + water (10 mL), 180 °C, 3 days; (3) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.50 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (1.0 mmol) + py (0.50 mL) + water (10 mL), 180 °C, 3 days; (4) Cd(Ac)2 · 2H2O (0.50 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (1.0 mmol) + py (0.50 mL) + water (10 mL), 180 °C, 3 days; (5) Cd(Ac)2·2H2O (1.0 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (1.0 mmol) + py (0.50 mL) + water (10 mL), 180 °C, 3 days; (6) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.50 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (0.50 mmol) + water (10 mL), adjusted to pH = 8 with 1 mol/L NaOH, 180 °C, 3 days; (7) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.50 mmol) + H3IDC (0.50 mmol) + bpy (0.50 mmol) + NaOH (0.50 mmol) + water (10 mL) 180 °C, 3 days. The yields reacted at 180 °C are higher than that reacted at 150 °C, and the yields using Cd/H3IDC/bpy = 1:1:1 molar ratio and NaOH to adjust pH value are also higher than those using Cd/H3IDC/bpy = 1:1:2 or 1:2:2 molar ratios and pyridine to adjust pH value. In all the cases, the pH values of the solutions before and after reactions are ca. 8 and 6, respectively.

elements.content: This compound could also be obtained in various yields by the hydrothermal reactions of Zn salts, H3IDC, and bpy with the following different molar ratios in 10 mL of water and 0.5 mL of py (or adjust pH value to 8 with NaOH) at 180 °C for 3 days:  ZnSO4/IDC/bpy = 1:0.5:1 (py as a base), Zn(NO3)2/IDC/bpy = 1:0.5:1 (py as a base), ZnSO4/IDC/bpy = 1:1:2 (NaOH as a base), and ZnSO4/IDC/bpy = 1:0.5:1 (NaOH as a base). In all the cases, the starting and final pH values of the solutions are ca. 8 and 6, respectively.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Single-crystal data for 1−3 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using direct method, which yielded the positions of all non-hydrogen atoms. These were refined first isotropically and then anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. The hydrogen atoms of HIDC2- and H2bpy2+ in 1 and coordinated water molecules in 2 were located in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically; the rationality of the hydrogen positions of HIDC2- and H2bpy2+ can be easily checked by the relative bond distances. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-97 system of computer programs. The crystallographic data are summarized in Table . The selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

Preparation Chemistry. The supramolecular structures of coordination polymers containing heterocyclic carboxylate ligands are very sensitive to the pH values of the solutions. By using the same building blocks, a series of coordination polymers with different structures can be constructed via changing the pH values. In this paper, three new coordination polymers have been constructed from the hydrothermal reactions of Cd(II) and Zn(II) with imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate and 4,4‘-bipyridyl under similar pH values. Compound 1 could be obtained in various yields by the hydrothermal reactions under different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions. In all cases, the final pH values of the solutions are around 6 when the reactions were ended. Under this pH value, four species of IDC3-, HIDC2-, bpy, and H2bpy2+ coexist in compound 1, and only the crystals of 1 were obtained with all the different Cd/IDC/bpy molar ratios we tried. While increasing the pH value to about 10 led to a different compound of {Na4[Cd7(IDC)6]·3bpy·7H2O} n , in which H3IDC is fully deprotonated (the final pH value ≈ 8). The results indicate that the structures constructed by Cd, IDC, and bpy are mainly controlled by the pH values of the solutions, while the different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions can only affect the yields of the formations of 1. It is worth noting that using pyridine instead of NaOH to adjust pH values and increasing the ratio of bpy will lower the yields of 1. This indicates there are competitive reactions between IDC with bpy and pyridine, i.e., excess bpy and pyridine will inhibit the coordination of IDC to Cd(II), and this leads to the formation of less amounts of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Preparation Chemistry. The supramolecular structures of coordination polymers containing heterocyclic carboxylate ligands are very sensitive to the pH values of the solutions. By using the same building blocks, a series of coordination polymers with different structures can be constructed via changing the pH values. In this paper, three new coordination polymers have been constructed from the hydrothermal reactions of Cd(II) and Zn(II) with imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate and 4,4‘-bipyridyl under similar pH values. Compound 1 could be obtained in various yields by the hydrothermal reactions under different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions. In all cases, the final pH values of the solutions are around 6 when the reactions were ended. Under this pH value, four species of IDC3-, HIDC2-, bpy, and H2bpy2+ coexist in compound 1, and only the crystals of 1 were obtained with all the different Cd/IDC/bpy molar ratios we tried. While increasing the pH value to about 10 led to a different compound of {Na4[Cd7(IDC)6]⋅3bpy⋅7H2O} n , in which H3IDC is fully deprotonated (the final pH value ~ 8). The results indicate that the structures constructed by Cd, IDC, and bpy are mainly controlled by the pH values of the solutions, while the different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions can only affect the yields of the formations of 1. It is worth noting that using pyridine instead of NaOH to adjust pH values and increasing the ratio of bpy will lower the yields of 1. This indicates there are competitive reactions between IDC with bpy and pyridine, i.e., excess bpy and pyridine will inhibit the coordination of IDC to Cd(II), and this leads to the formation of less amounts of 1.

elements.content: The preparations of 2 and 3 show a more complex situation than that of 1; the formations of 2 and 3 are influenced by the pH values, the different Zn salts and Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios. No matter what kinds of Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios were used, only unidentified powders were obtained when the final pH values are over 7. Lowering the final pH values to ca. 6 led to the formations of 2 and 3, in which all the IDC ligands are fully deprotonated. The results indicate that the formations of fully deprotonated Cd(II) compounds need a higher pH value, while a higher pH value will generate the precipitation of the Zn ion due to its smaller ion radius. It seems in general that ZnSO4 prefers to form 2, and Zn(NO3)2 prefers to generate 3, and lowering the IDC ratio can lead to the formation of more compound 2. In addition, the yields of 3 are always low (less than 5%) under all the experimental conditions we have tried. Although at present we have not fully understood how the different Zn salts and Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios affect the formations of 2 or 3, it seems that only these two kinds of crystals of 2 and 3 were obtained whatever Zn salts and Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios were used when the final pH value was controlled at about 6.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of {(H 2 bpy)[Cd 9 (HIDC) 4 (IDC) 4 (bpy) 4 ] · 8H 2 O} n (1). Compound 1 contains three crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions (Figure a); in which Cd(1) is six-coordinated with two oxygen (O(1) and O(5)) and two nitrogen (N(1) and N(3)) atoms from two individual μ3-HIDC2- (Scheme a) and μ4-IDC3- (Scheme c), and two oxygen atoms (O(1A) and O(7B)) from each adjacent μ3-HIDC2- and μ5-IDC3- (Scheme d); Cd(2) is six-coordinated with two oxygen (O(4) and O(7)) and two nitrogen (N(2) and N(4)) atoms from each μ3-HIDC2- and μ5-IDC3-, one nitrogen atom N(5) from μ2-bpy, and one oxygen atom O(5B) from adjacent μ4-IDC3-; Cd(3) is six-coordinated with four oxygen atoms (O(8), O(8A), O(8B), O(8C)) from two μ5-IDC3, and two nitrogen atoms (N(6), N(6A)) from two monodentate bpy molecules. Each μ3-HIDC2-, μ4-IDC3-, and μ5-IDC3- is quasi-planar, with the mean deviations from the planes being 0.0316, 0.0244, and 0.0207 Å, respectively. The μ3-HIDC2- bridges the Cd(II) ions in a asymmetrical mode, while μ4-IDC3- and μ5-IDC3- connect the Cd(II) ions in a symmetrical way, in which each of the μ4-IDC3- and μ5-IDC3- lies in a C 2 symmetry (Figure a).

elements.content: In 1, two μ3-HIDC2-, one μ4-IDC3-, one μ5-IDC3-, and four Cd(II) ions form a molecular square of [Cd4(μ3-HIDC)2(μ4-IDC)(μ5-IDC)]2- (Figure b), in which the μ3-HIDC2- plane is perpendicular to the μ4-IDC3- and μ5-IDC3- planes with the dihedral angles of 92.0° and 93.9°, respectively. The square resides on an symmetrical plane with the Cd(1)···Cd(2), Cd(1)···Cd(1A), and Cd(2)···Cd(2A) separations of 6.59, 6.72, and 6.66 Å, respectively. Two [Cd4(μ3-HIDC)2(μ4-IDC)(μ5-IDC)]2- square are connected together via four μ2-O(1) of μ3-HIDC2- to form a “double-square” of [Cd4(μ3-HIDC)2(μ4-IDC)(μ5-IDC)]2 4- (Figure c). The “double-square” are then connected with Cd(3) through the μ5-IDC3- to lead to 1D infinite chain of {Cd(bpy)2[Cd4(μ3-HIDC)2(μ4-IDC)(μ5-IDC)]2} n 2 n - (≡ [Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)2] n 2 n -, Figure c). The 1D chains are further interlinked through μ2-bpy to result in a 2D brick-wall-like network of [Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)2(μ2-bpy)2] n 2 n - (≡ [Cd9(HIDC)4(IDC)4(bpy)4] n 2 n -) along the ab plane (Figure d). Each “brick” is constructed by two “double-square”, two Cd(3) atoms, four monodentate bpy, and four μ2-bpy with the dimensions of 25.7 × 11.8 × 6.7 Å (Figure d). The protonated bpy ions H2bpy2+ and water molecules are located in the “bricks”. The adjacent 2D brick walls are perpendicularly packed and interlinked by the μ2-O(5) from μ4-IDC3- and μ2-O(7) from μ5-IDC3-, a 3D MOF of 1 is generated by the alternate connections of two perpendicular 2D walls (Figure e).

The square resides on an symmetrical plane with the Cd(1)⋅⋅⋅Cd(2), Cd(1)⋅⋅⋅Cd(1A), and Cd(2)⋅⋅⋅Cd(2A) separations of 6.59, 6.72, and 6.66 Å, respectively. elements.content: The most striking feature of 1 is that each “brick” contains two “double-square” units (Figure d). In addition, the species of μ3-HIDC2-, μ4-IDC3-, μ5-IDC3-, H2bpy2+, μ2-bpy, and monodentate bpy coexisting in one compound are very unusual. To the best of our knowledge, the above two unique features of 1 have not been found in the reported imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate complexes and its analogues.

elements.content: [Zn 3 (IDC) 2 (bpy)(H 2 O) 2 ] n (2). The asymmetrical unit of the unit cell contains half Zn(1), one Zn(2), one μ3-IDC3-, half μ2-bpy, and one water molecule (Figure a). Zn(1) is located on an inversion center and shows different coordination environments and geometry from Zn(2). Each Zn(1) is six-coordinated with two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms from two individual μ3-IDC3- (Scheme b) in the equatorial plane, and two water molecules in axial positions, forming a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. The axial Zn−O bond distance (2.252(2) Å) is longer than the equatorial Zn−O and Zn−N bond distances (2.146(2) and 2.008 Å). Each Zn(2) shows a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment and is five coordinated with two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen atom from one μ2-bpy and two individual μ3-IDC3- in the equatorial plane, and two oxygen atoms from two individual μ3-IDC3- in axial positions. The axial Zn−O bond distances (2.044(2) and 2.178(2) Å) are slightly longer than the equatorial Zn−O (1.993(2) Å) and Zn−N bond distances (2.043(2) Å). Each μ3-IDC3- anion connects three Zn(II) ions in a symmetrical coordination mode (Scheme b). The four carboxylic oxygen atoms of μ3-IDC3- are not lie in the plane of the imidazole ring, with the deviations of 0.308, 0.218, 0.165, and 0.220 Å out of the plane for O(1), O(2), O(3), and O(4), respectively. The coordination environments of the Zn ions in 2 are different from those in a recent reported compound of {[Co3(IDC)2(bpy)(H2O)4]·2H2O} n , in which both Co(1) and Co(2) are six-coordinated with octahedral geometries.

elements.content: In 2, all the Zn(II) ions are bridged by μ3-IDC3- to generate a 2D wavelike sheet of [Zn3(IDC)2(H2O)2] n containing 24-membered rings (Figure b). Each 24-membered ring shows a chain-conformation and is formed by six μ3-IDC3- anions, two octahedral Zn(II), and four trigonal bipyramidal Zn(II) cations. The adjacent 2D wavelike sheets are further connected by μ2-bpy bridges to result in a 3D coordination polymer (Figure c). Similar 2D sheet of [Co3(IDC)2(H2O)4] n with 24-membered rings (constructed by six μ3-IDC3- and six Co(II)) are also formed in {[Co3(IDC)2(bpy)(H2O)4]·2H2O} n . However, the cavity of the 24-membered ring in cobalt compound is much larger than that in compound 2 due to the six-coordinated Co(II) ions, so each μ2-bpy bridge can pass through the large cavity to connect the adjacent two sheets to result in an interpenetrating 3D framework.

However, the cavity of the 24-membered ring in cobalt compound is much larger than that in compound 2 due to the six-coordinated Co(II) ions, so each μ2-bpy bridge can pass through the large cavity to connect the adjacent two sheets to result in an interpenetrating 3D framework.

elements.content: {[Zn 3 (IDC) 2 (bpy) 3 ] · (bpy) · 8H 2 O} n (3). The MOF of this compound is similar to that of a recent reported compound of {[Co3(IDC)2(bpy)3]·6H2O·DMF} n , which is constructed by connecting the 2D honeycomb-like sheets of [Zn3(IDC)2] n with μ2-bpy bridges. As shown in Figure a, three crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions are all located on inversion centers. Each Zn(1) atom is six-coordinated with four oxygen atoms from two individual μ3-IDC3- in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two different μ2-bpy in the axial positions. The six-coordinated Zn(2) and Zn(3) atoms show similar coordination environments with two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two μ3-IDC3- occupying the equatorial positions, and two nitrogen atoms from μ2-bpy occupying the axial positions. One of the carboxylate (O(3), O(4)) of μ3-IDC3- bridge is coplanar with the imidazole ring (mean deviation from the plane = 0.018 Å), while the other carboxylate (O(1), O(2)) lies slightly out of the plane with the deviations of 0.271 and 0.329 Å for O(1) and O(2), respectively.

elements.content: Similar to compound 2, each μ3-IDC3- in 3 bridges three Zn(II) ions in a symmetrical coordination mode to generate a 2D honeycomb-like sheet of [Zn3(IDC)2] n with 24-membered hexagonal rings (Figure b). The 2D honeycomb-like sheet of 3 is different from the 2D wavelike sheet of 2, although they have the same [Zn3(IDC)2] n composition. In 3, the 24-membered hexagonal ring contains two ZnO4 and four ZnO2N2 coordination spheres, while the 24-membered chair-conformational ring in 2 involves two ZnO2N2 and four ZnO3N cores. The 2D honeycomb-like sheets in 3 are further pillared by μ2-bpy to give a 3D coordination polymer with open hexagonal channels along the a axis and tetragonal channels along the [01̄1] plane (Figure c). The hexagonal and tetragonal channels are occupied by water and bpy guest molecules, respectively.

elements.content: Thermal Analyses, X-ray Powder Diffraction and Photoluminescent Properties. The results of thermogravimetric (TG) analyses indicate that compound 1 lost its water molecules below 220 °C (Figure ), the weight loss found of 1.9% was consistent with that calculated (2.0%). After the loss of water molecules, the 3D framework was stable up to 330 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 showed an initial weight loss of 4.4% from 100 to 260 °C corresponding to the removal of two coordination water molecules per formula unit (calcd. 5.2%), and then the compound was stable up to 410 °C, followed by another weight loss after that temperature. Compound 3 showed a weight loss of 8.3% around 100 °C, which closely matches the weight loss of 10.1% for removing the eight water guest molecules per formula unit from the channels of 3. The MOF of 3 was stable to about 170 °C, and then it began to decompose with a continuous weight loss up to 480 °C. The results indicate that the 3D frameworks of 1 and 2 can be thermally stable at high temperature, while the MOF of 3 is less thermal stable. The relative lower stability of 3 may be due to its large volume of the channels, which is easy to collapse upon heating.

elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was used to check the purity of compounds 1 and 2. As shown in Figure , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns closely match those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, indicating single phases of 1 and 2 are formed. The XRPD patterns at different temperatures (Figure ) indicate that the frameworks of 1 and 2 are stable up to 320 and 400 °C, respectively, which are consistent with the results of TG analyses. XRD pattern of 3 was not measured due to its too small amount of sample. It should be mentioned that the positions and intensities of some peaks in the measured patterns of 2 were changed when the sample was heated over 200 °C; probably the phase transition from single crystals to single crystals occurred. A detailed investigation is ongoing.

elements.content: Previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing cadmium and zinc exhibit photoluminescent properties. Hence, we also investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1 and 2 (Figure ). In the solid state, strong photoluminescence emission bands at 555 nm (λex = 467 nm) and 564 nm (λex = 470 nm) are observed for 1 and 2, respectively. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480 nm, there is no obvious emission observed for free H3IDC under the same experimental conditions, while free bpy ligand presents weak photoluminescence emission at 486 nm. Therefore, the fluorescent emissions in the two coordination polymers may be proposed to originate from the coordination of HIDC2- or IDC3- to the cadmium or zinc atoms (ligand-to-metal charge transition, LMCT).

elements.content: In conclusion, by selecting the Cd(II) and Zn(II) ions as knots, and H3IDC and bpy as building blocks, three 3D coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions. The formation of 1 is mainly controlled by the pH value of the solution, and the different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions lead to the formations of the same compound of 1 at pH ≈ 6, while the formations of 2 and 3 are both influenced by the pH values of the solutions and the different Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios. The different reactivity between Cd(II) and Zn(II) is due to their differences in ion radii. The framework of 2 shows a highly stability over 400 °C, while the framework of 3 is much less stable than those of 1 and 2 due to its large volume of channels which is easy to collapse upon heating.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, by selecting the Cd(II) and Zn(II) ions as knots, and H3IDC and bpy as building blocks, three 3D coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions. The formation of 1 is mainly controlled by the pH  value of the solution, and the different Cd/IDC/bpy compositions lead to the formations of the same compound of 1 at pH ~ 6, while the formations of 2 and 3 are both influenced by the pH values of the solutions and the different Zn/IDC/bpy molar ratios. The different reactivity between Cd(II) and Zn(II) is due to their differences in ion radii. The framework of 2 shows a highly stability over 400 °C, while the framework of 3 is much less stable than those of 1 and 2 due to its large volume of channels which is easy to collapse upon heating.

{(H 2 bpy)[Cd 9 (HIDC) 4 (IDC) 4 (bpy) 4 ] · 8H 2 O} n (1). A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.154 g, 0.50 mmol), H3IDC (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), bpy (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), pyridine (py, 0.50 mL), and water (10 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 180 °C for 3 days, followed by cooling to 100 °C at a rate of 10 °C /h, and held at this temperature for 10 h, then cooled to room temperature. The pH values of the solution before and after reactions are ca. 8 and 6, respectively. Colorless block crystals were collected by hand, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield:  43.8% based on Cd(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. found: C, 34.47, H, 1.96, N, 11.82%. Calcd for C90H62N26O36Cd9: C, 34.92, H, 2.02, N, 11.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3426 (m), 1602 (vs), 1475 (vs), 1378 (s), 1243 (s), 1107 (m), 805 (m), 664 (w), 630 (w).

[Zn 3 (IDC) 2 (bpy)(H 2 O) 2 ] n (2). A mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.144 g, 0.50 mmol), H3IDC (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), bpy (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), py (0.50 mL), and water (10 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 180 °C for 3 days, followed by cooling to 100 °C at a rate of 10 °C /h and held at this temperature for 10 h and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless prism-shaped crystals were collected by hand, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield:  54.0% based on Zn(SO4)2·7H2O. Anal. found C, 34.41, H, 2.18, N, 12.15%. Calcd for C20H14N6O10Zn3:  C, 34.56, H, 2.02, N, 12.10%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3109 (m), 1621 (vs), 1592 (vs), 1551 (s), 1475 (s), 1425 (s), 1389 (s), 1245 (m), 1106 (m), 1079 (m), 1012 (m), 865 (m), 836 w, 794 (m), 670 (m), 643 (m).

{[Zn 3 (IDC) 2 (bpy) 3 ] · (bpy) · 8H 2 O} n (3). This compound was prepared by a similar procedure to 2 from a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.149 g, 0.50 mmol), H3IDC (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), bpy (0.078 g, 0.50 mmol), py (0.5 mL), and water (6 mL) in low yield. Anal. Calcd for C50H52N12O17Zn3 (3·H2O):  C, 46.58, H, 4.06, N, 13.04%. Found C, 46.19, H, 4.31, N, 13.06%. IR (KBr cm-1):  3410 (m), 3056 (m), 1591 (vs), 1469 (m), 1387 (s), 1246 (m), 1102 (m), 824 (w), 663 (w).

cln_elements.content:
Thermal Analyses, X-ray Powder Diffraction and Photoluminescent Properties. The results of thermogravimetric (TG) analyses indicate that compound 1 lost its water molecules below 220 °C (Figure ), the weight loss found of 1.9% was consistent with that calculated (2.0%). After the loss of water molecules, the 3D framework was stable up to 330 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 showed an initial weight loss of 4.4% from 100 to 260 °C corresponding to the removal of two coordination water molecules per formula unit (calcd. 5.2%), and then the compound was stable up to 410 °C, followed by another weight loss after that temperature. Compound 3 showed a weight loss of 8.3% around 100 °C, which closely matches the weight loss of 10.1% for removing the eight water guest molecules per formula unit from the channels of 3. The MOF of 3 was stable to about 170 °C, and then it began to decompose with a continuous weight loss up to 480 °C. The results indicate that the 3D frameworks of 1 and 2 can be thermally stable at high temperature, while the MOF of 3 is less thermal stable. The relative lower stability of 3 may be due to its large volume of the channels, which is easy to collapse upon heating.

Previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing cadmium and zinc exhibit photoluminescent properties. Hence, we also investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1 and 2 (Figure ). In the solid state, strong photoluminescence emission bands at 555 nm (λex = 467 nm) and 564 nm (λex = 470 nm) are observed for 1 and 2, respectively. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480 nm, there is no obvious emission observed for free H3IDC under the same experimental conditions, while free bpy ligand presents weak photoluminescence emission at 486 nm. Therefore, the fluorescent emissions in the two coordination polymers may be proposed to originate from the coordination of HIDC2- or IDC3- to the cadmium or zinc atoms (ligand-to-metal charge transition, LMCT).

cln_elements.content: (a) The segment of compound1, showing the local coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and μ3-HIDC2-, μ4-IDC3-, μ5-IDC3- bridges. (b) The molecular square in compound 1. (c) The 1D chain constructed by the alternating connections of “double square” units with Cd(3) atoms in 1. (d) The 2D brick-wall-like structures with each “brick” containing one H2bpy2+ guest molecule. Each monodentate bpy molecule connected to Cd(3) is drawn as one nitrogen atom for clarity (O, red; C, gray; N, dark blue; Cd, pink). (e) The perpendicularly packing of two 2D brick walls (marked as red and blue) along the c axis (left). Each monodentate bpy molecule connected to Cd(3) is drawn as one atom, and the water molecules are omitted for clarity. The 3D MOF of 1 is constructed by the alternate red/blue connections (left).

(d) The 2D brick-wall-like structures with each "brick" containing one H2bpy2+ guest molecule. Each monodentate bpy molecule connected to Cd(3) is drawn as one nitrogen atom for clarity (O, red; C, gray; N, dark blue; Cd, pink). (e) The perpendicularly packing of two 2D brick walls (marked as red and blue) along the c axis (left). Each monodentate bpy molecule connected to Cd(3) is drawn as one atom, and the water molecules are omitted for clarity. The 3D MOF of 1 is constructed by the alternate red/blue connections (left).

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of the Zn(II) and IDC3- ions in 2. (b) The 2D wavelike sheet with chair-conformational 24-membered rings viewed along the a axis (left) and c axis (right) for 2. Coordinated water molecules and bpy ligands are omitted for clarity (O, red; C, gray; N, dark blue; Cd, green (five-coordinated) and pink (six-coordinated)). (c) The 3D framework of 2 viewed along the c axis, which are constructed by the connecting 2D wavelike sheets with μ2-bpy bridges.

metadata.title:
Three 3D Coordination Polymers Constructed by Cd(II) and Zn(II)
with Imidazole-4,5-Dicarboxylate and 4,4‘-Bipyridyl Building Blocks
